{@i When playing in the Depths of Melokir campaign you may not Multiclass into or out of this class if you have selected this Subclass, nor can you select this Subclass if you are already Multiclassing}

As a Forge Adept, you carry on these ancient traditions, creating mystical weapons and armor, strengthening allies on the battlefield, and bringing down enemies with weapons imbued with your own soul energy. If you’re dar, you learned these techniques from the masters of your clan. Are you content to follow ancient traditions, or do you want to add your own innovations? If you’re not Dhakaani, did you learn these techniques from a daashor mentor? Did you steal this knowledge? Or are you replicating these traditions on your own?

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: When you adopt this specialization at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with smith’s tools. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan’s tools of your choice.

entries.name: Forge Adept Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Forge Adept Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don’t count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

entries.caption: Forge Adept Spells
rows: {@spell armor of agathys}, {@spell shield of faith}

subclassFeature.name: Battle Ready
entries: When you reach 3rd level, your combat training and your experiments with magic have paid off in two ways:

items.entry: You gain proficiency with martial weapons.
When you attack with a magic weapon, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Ghaal'shaarat
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to imbue a weapon with a fraction of your spirit. The Dhakaani daashors called this weapon the ghaal’shaarat, Goblin for “mighty blade.” Imbuing your ghaal’shaarat works like infusing an item, but does not count toward your maximum number of infused items.

When you finish a long rest, you can touch a magic or nonmagical simple or martial melee weapon, which becomes your ghaal’shaarat. Once imbued, your ghaal’shaarat is a magic weapon that grants a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls. If the base weapon you imbued already grants such a bonus, you instead only take the higher bonus. This bonus increases when you reach certain levels in this class, increasing to +2 at 8th level and +3 at 13th level. If the weapon you imbued has the thrown property, it returns to your hand immediately after it is used to make a ranged attack.

Your ghaal’shaarat’s benefits remain until the weapon is destroyed or until you use this ability to imbue a new item with this power. Other creatures can’t benefit from your ghaal’shaarat’s powers, and to them, it functions as the unimbued weapon did.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Runes of War
entries: At 9th level, you gain the ability to enhance the weapons of your squad, targeting the damage to the weakness of your enemies.

As an action, you can activate an aura that extends from you in a 30-foot radius. The aura moves with you, centered on you, and lasts for 1 minute or until your concentration ends (as if you were casting a spell). When you activate this aura, choose one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. Each creature of your choice in the aura deals an extra 1d4 damage of the chosen type when it hits with a weapon attack.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Perfect Weapon
entries: At 15th level, you learn how to imbue your ghaal’shaarat with additional power, and how to draw on it in time of need. The first time you attack with your ghaal’shaarat on your turn, you can transfer some or all of its bonus to your armor class, instead of using the bonus on any attacks that turn. For every 1 you reduce your attack and damage rolls by, you gain +1 to your AC. As long as you continue holding your ghaal’shaarat, the AC bonus remains in effect until the start of your next turn.
Additionally, when you finish a long rest, you can select one of the following benefits.
Until you finish your next long rest, you gain the selected benefit whenever you’re holding your ghaal’shaarat.

items.entry: You have resistance to psychic damage, and you can’t be charmed or frightened.

You use your ghaal’shaarat to channel the elements. When you select this ability, select one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. When you hit with your ghaal’shaarat, the target takes an extra 1d6 damage of the chosen type.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Card
entries: {@i This subclass was originally published in: Legends of Runeterra: Dark Tides of Bilgewater}

{@i When playing in the Depths of Melokir campaign you may not Multiclass into or out of this class if you have selected this Subclass, nor can you select this Subclass if you are already Multiclassing}
Some rogues favor honing their skill and precision, others perfect a silver tongue, but you — well, you’ve always gotten a kick out of leaving things up to chance.

Rogues of the Wild Card variety thrive on the high stakes and random thrill of the game table. Armed with cunning cheats and no small amount of luck, these sly gamblers live and die by their rules, never keen to simply accept the hand fate deals them.

entries.name: Tricks Up the Sleeve
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your penchant for games has afforded you the ability to subtly manipulate fortune to your favor. When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn the Guidance cantrip. Starting at 9th level, it has a range of 30 feet for you, and you can cast it as a bonus action.

entries.name: Wild Card’s Gambit
entries: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with one of the following gaming sets: dice set, dragonchess set, or playing card set.

The gaming set you choose grants you a Wild Card’s Gambit, as detailed below. If you are proficient in multiple types of gaming sets, you must choose which gambit to use when you gain this feature. You can change your choice of gambit whenever you gain a level in this class.

entries.name: Dragonchess
entries: Your prowess of the chessboard has made you a skilled tactician on the battlefield. As a bonus action on your turn, you can execute one of the following chess maneuvers. You can use a bonus action in this way a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and regain all uses after a long rest.

items.name: Dragon
items.entry: Choose a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The first time that creature makes a successful attack roll before the start of your next turn, they deal extra damage equal to your level in this class.

items.name: Griffon
items.entry: You take the Dash action, and your movement does not provoke opportunity attacks. These benefits last until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Sylph
items.entry: Choose creatures up to your Charisma modifier within 30 feet of you, they have advantage on Dexterity saving throws until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Loaded Dice
entries: You gain a pool of d6s equal to the number of d6s you roll for your Sneak Attack damage. (Your pool starts with 2d6 at 3rd level, and increases to 3d6 at 5th level, and so on.) When a creature targets you with an attack, you can use your reaction to spend one die from the pool and subtract the number rolled from the attack. You can choose to use this feature after the creature makes its roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack roll hits or misses. Starting at 9th level you can spend up to two dice from the pool at once, and starting at 17th level you can spend up to three dice at once. You regain all expended dice from your loaded dice pool when you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Playing Cards
entries: You have developed a fighting style based around the cartomancy of the Serpent Isles. You have your own deck of enchanted cards, and can make their edges razor-sharp with a flick of your wrist. If you have not yet used your Sneak Attack this turn, you can use your action to take one of these cards and attack a creature within 30 feet with it. The attack roll for this feature uses your Dexterity modifier, and on a hit, it deals slashing damage equal 1d4 + your Dexterity modifier. When you roll for damage, look at the number rolled on the d4. The attack gains a random effect based on the number rolled, as detailed in the Wild Card Suit table below. You can attack using a card in this manner a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and regain all uses after a long rest.

entries.caption: Wild Card Suit Table
rows: Blade: Roll your Sneak Attack damage and add it to your razor card’s damage. At the start of its next turn, the target takes additional damage equal to half the Sneak Attack damage rolled.
Shackle: Until the start of your next turn, the target’s speed is halved. It can’t make more than one attack on its turn while its speed is reduced in this way.

Heart: Roll your Sneak Attack damage and add it to your razor card’s damage. You also immediately regain a number of hit points equal to the half the damage dealt. Any excess hit points regained become temporary hit points.
Wild Ace: This card morphs suits depending on the dealer’s wishes. Choose Blade, Shackle, or Heart. The card then immediately gains the suit’s respective effect.

subclassFeature.name: Shifting the Odds
entries: Starting at 9th level, you are acutely aware of how to quit when you’re ahead, vanishing in a flash when the odds begin to turn against you. As a bonus action, you can disappear with a dramatic flourish. Each creature within 10 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier), taking 4d10 force damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

You then teleport yourself to an unoccupied space that you can see within 120 feet of your original location. Once you have used this ability, you cannot use it again until you have finished a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Twist of Fate
entries: At 13th level, your mastery over the game table hones your speed and cunning in combat. After rolling initiative but before the first turn of combat, you can choose to swap places in the initiative order with one creature you can see. If the creature is one of your allies, that ally must agree to swapping initiative with you.

subclassFeature.name: Joker Wild
entries: At 17th level, your mastery over chance encompasses even your own form, allowing you to exist between potential realities. As a bonus action on your turn, you can take on an incorporeal form, during which you gain the following benefits:
You regain expended power for your Wild Card’s Gambit feature:

items.entry: Cards. You regain all spent uses of that feature.
Dragonchess. You regain all spent uses of that feature.
Dice. You regain all spent dice.
Your movement speed is doubled.
You gain resistance to all damage, and are immune to the grappled, paralyzed, stunned, and restrained conditions.

You can move through objects and creatures as if they were difficult terrain. If you end your turn inside a creature, the creature takes 1d10 force damage and is shunted into an adjacent space within 5 feet of their original location.

entries: This incorporeal state lasts for one minute, or until you are incapacitated. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest

subclassFeature.name: Veildancer
entries: {@i This subclass was written by: @thefantasticemporium}

{@i When playing in the Depths of Melokir campaign you may not Multiclass into or out of this class if you have selected this Subclass, nor can you select this Subclass if you are already Multiclassing}

entries.name: Mirage weavers and blade spinners
entries: This conclave of rangers originate from large spaces where the horizon doesn’t provide much cover, except for mirages. They often hail from sand deserts, their steamy dunes and their secret oasis providing safe haven; but other places, like swamps or sea can be full of misty visions and illusions.

These rangers have learned to take advantage of these natural effects, and use them as a tool to hide, disguise or blur themselves and their allies. They weave the appearance of the world around them to get the upper hand and provide protection, mobility and increased offensive prowess to their allies.

entries.name: Veil Dancer Magic
entries: At 3rd level, your bond with mirage and illusions shows in your magic abilities. you learn the Minor Illusion cantrip.

You also learn an additional spell of 1st level or higher when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Veil Dancer Spells table bellow. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn’t count against the number of ranger spells you know.

Also at 3rd level, you have learned to quickly weave a cloak of illusions around you or your allies, called a Veil. As a bonus action, you target a willing creature that you can see within 30 ft. (including you) and give it one of the following Veils. A Veil lasts for its whole duration, until you use this ability again or until magic dispels it.

items.entry: Deceiving Veil: you change the way a willing creature looks for 1 hour, as per the spell Disguise Self. This effect ceases if the creature stops to be willing.
Concealing Veil: your veil provides camouflage. For 1 hour, the target has advantage to its Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

Shimmering Veil: you blur the image of a creature, whose silhouette seems to shift quickly and undulate. For 1 minute, all attacks against the target are made with disadvantage, unless they are incapacitated, restrained or otherwise unable to move.

entries: These Veils are perfect tools for a deadly ambush. When a creature benefiting from this feature hits a creature with a weapon during the first round of a combat, they can deal an extra 1d6 damage to the target, which can take this extra damage only once during this fight. This damage goes up to 2d6 at 7th level and to 3d6 at 11th level.
If the creature that benefit from one of these Veils takes damage, the feature ceases to function until the start of their next turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Elusive Shrouds
entries: At 7th level, you have mastered the art of weaving fast and confusing illusions, as your veils now embrace each of your whims and movements with a disorienting grace. You gain the following features:

items.entry: You can use an action to change the appearance of your Deceiving Veil at will without expending another use of this ability, as long as the target is willing and in range. This doesn’t change the Veil’s total duration.
Creatures under the effect of your Concealing Veil can attempt to hide even while directly observed.
Creatures under the effect of your Shimmering Veil don’t trigger attacks of opportunity when they move, as each step taken seems to make them blink in and out of sight for a second.

subclassFeature.name: Vaporous Dodge
entries: At 11th level, those affected by your mirages are never truly where they seem to be. Whenever a creature under the effect of one of your Veils receives damage, they can use their reaction to teleport up to 30 ft. in an unoccupied space they can either see or have occupied in the last minute.

subclassFeature.name: Misty Warriors
entries: At 15th level, your mirages can target more creatures and even affect the material plane. You can create one of the following effects as a bonus action while you are under the effect of one of your Veils or as part of the bonus action used to activate your Veil of Mirages. Once you have used this feature, you cannot do so again until you take a short or long rest:

items.entry: You summon tangible and identical illusions of you. You can summon a number of doubles equal to your Wisdom modifier in points of your choice that you can see within 30ft. of you. Each double benefits from your Veil and makes an attack against a target of your choice when it appears, as if you were making an attack with the weapon you have in hand. After each double has attacked, you can choose to swap places with one of your doubles. The doubles last until the start of your next turn, they share your AC, are immune to poison and psychic damage, and they disappear if they take at least 1 point of damage.

You target a number of willing creatures that you can see within 30 ft. of you inferior or equal to your Wisdom modifier. Each creature benefits from the current Veil of Mirages that you have chosen for its entire duration or until you lose your concentration, as if you were concentrating on a spell. If you lose your concentration, you don’t lose your own Veil, only the other targets do. If you apply your Deceiving Veil in this way you can choose a different appearance for each individual target. A target of this feature loses its benefits if they start or end their turns more than 60ft. from you.

subclassFeature.name: Unstoppable Force
entries: {@i 18th-level Office of the Wight feature}
You have reached the apex of your Office, becoming a herculean undead with strength only matched by the spirit that flows through your core. You gain the following benefits:

items.entry: Your base size is large - using Juggernaut increases your size to Huge.

You can treat {@condition grappled} creatures as a shield, providing +2 AC against creatures that are not the {@condition grappled} creature - this does not reduce the damage die used by the Unarmed Fighting Style.
Your Office features ignore resistance to bludgeoning damage, and treat immunity as resistance.
You treat 1s on damage die for Office features as a 3.

subclassFeature.name: Meat Shield
entries: {@i 15th-level Office of the Hulk feature}

Your strength only grows. You gain expertise in {@skill Athletics}. Additionally, as a reaction to a creature you are not grappling making an attack roll against you, you may use a creature you are grappling as a meat shield: make an athletics check against the attack roll. If you succeed, the attack targets the {@condition grappled} creature instead.

subclassFeature.name: Vigor Mortis
entries: {@i 11th-level Office of the Hulk feature}

As your ability to apply brute force waxes, you find new ways to really apply the hurt. When you succeed on a grappling check either to grapple someone or to prevent someone from escaping a grapple, you can apply one of the following:

entries.name: Floor Slam
entries: You slam the creature against the ground: they take (PROF){@dice D6} magical bludgeoning damage and must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Wrack DC. on a failure, they are knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Suplex
entries: You suplex the creature: They take {@dice 3d4} magical bludgeoning damage and must make a Constitution saving throw against your Wrack DC: on a failure, they become {@condition stunned} until the start of your next turn and are moved to the other side of you, given that that is a safe space for them to be placed on.

entries.name: Lariat
entries: You physically spin the creature around you. Creatures within 5ft of you and the {@condition grappled} creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Wrack DC: on a failure, they take (PROF) {@dice d4} magical bludgeoning damage. If a creature fails by 5 or more, they become dazed until the end of their next turn.

entries.name: Fastball
entries: You throw the creature at a solid surface you can see within 30ft of you. The thrown creature and any creature in the square chosen must make a Strength saving throw against your Wrack DC: on a failure, they take (PROF) {@dice d8} magical bludgeoning damage, or half on success.

You can use this a maximum of twice per round, and must choose a different one for each time in a round. Additionally, you can grapple creatures of up to two size categories larger than you, and can brace a creature of up to one size larger than you using your wrack.

subclassFeature.name: Juggernaut
entries: {@i 6th-level Office of the Hulk feature}
You are able to channel necrotic energy to directly increase your size. As a bonus action, you magically gain the following benefits, which lasts for 1 minute:

items.entry: If you are smaller than large, you become Large, along with anything you are wearing. If you lack the room to become Large, your size doesn't change.
You have advantage on strength Checks and Strength saving throws.
You gain 5ft of movement speed.
Your movement speed is not reduced by dragging a creature.

entries: You can use this feature once, and cannot do so again unless you complete a short or long rest, unless you expend two necrotic charges to do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Consumption of Spirit
entries: {@i 3rd-level Office of the Hulk feature}

You gain an additional way to regain Necrotic Charges: Once per round, whenever you succeed on a Shove check, Grapple check, check to resist a Grapple escape, or a Grapple check to climb onto a larger creature, you can gain a Necrotic Charge.

subclassFeature.name: Wrack Foes: Wrack with Force
entries: {@i 3rd-level Office of the Hulk feature}

You channel necrotic energy into your decayed muscles, charging forward with unstoppable strength. Move up to your remaining movement speed +5ft in a straight line, or up to your movement speed being able to turn at 10ft intervals, passing through creatures without incurring extra movement and not provoking opportunity attacks. Each creature in the path must succeed on a Strength saving throw or take {@dice 2d8}+STR magical bludgeoning damage and are pushed 5ft away from the path, taking half as much damage and not being pushed away on a success. This wrack uses your regular movement speed as you charge.

If you are grappling a creature when you use this wrack that is of your size category or smaller, you can also brace them in front of you when you charge: that {@condition grappled} creature must make a Strength saving throw or take {@damage 2d4} bludgeoning damage for each creature, wall or object collided with during the charge, or half on a success. This bracing is only usable on one creature per charge.
This feature's damage increases to {@dice 2d10}+STR and {@dice 3d4} respectively at level 6, {@dice 2d12}+STR and {@dice 4d4} at level 10, and {@dice 3d10}+STR and {@dice 5d4} at level 15.

subclassFeature.name: Never Out of Reach
entries: {@i 1st-level Office of the Hulk feature}
Your revenant strength allows you to achieve superhuman feats. Once per short rest, you can cast the {@spell Jump} spell on yourself.
At level 5, when you do so you can grapple a creature once as a free action during that jump. At level 12, you get two uses of this feature per short rest and can cast this spell as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Tireless Strength
entries: {@i 1st-level Office of the Hulk feature}

The intense fervour that fuels your strength beyond the grave holds an iron grip on your foes. You add your Charisma modifier to grappling checks, and whenever you start your turn with a creature {@condition grappled} they take {@dice 1d6}+PROF magical bludgeoning damage.

subclassFeature.name: Office of the Hulk
entries: Sometimes, the most powerful undead is not the one raised through the most complicated rituals. Nor is it the undead with the most esoteric powers. Sometimes, it's just a corpse risen with a lot of energy and a lot of muscle, pointed at the enemy.

Returned out of the grave with newfound brawn, energy courses through your veins to enhance your strength and crush all who stand before you to form the front line of a dread army. Whether utilised as part of a horde to throw at a problem, or a more unique specimen sent in as a siege-breaker, your strength ensured that there was naught left in your wake.

Eventually, the shackles of your raising have slipped, and now the only will to guide your hands is your own. Some may call you an abomination, a monster, an unholy amalgm: but for all that you are adrift, you can be certain that your strength is finally, truly, your own.

spell.name: True Legend Lore

time.note: can be done as part of a short rest

entries: This spell allows to caster to briefly read the pattern of the fabric of reality itself in order to glimpse a moment of the ancient past, including moments that predate the gods. This spell seems to have been specially wrought to provide the caster with information about the Verdigris. When cast, the caster will receive a vivid vision of the ancient past, and learn something about the Verdigris’ secret past. Furthermore, any creature who has cast this spell will occasionally gain the ability to decern the literal meaning of words written in the Verdigris script.
Mystra was not consulted in the creation of the spell.
